break_even.title: Break-Even Calculator
break_even.description: This calculator helps you determine when your business will cover all expenses and start generating profit.
break_even.fixed_costs_tooltip: Costs that remain constant regardless of production volume (e.g., rent, salaries).
break_even.price_per_unit_tooltip: The price at which you sell one unit of your product or service.
break_even.variable_cost_per_unit_tooltip: Direct costs associated with producing one unit (e.g., raw materials).
break_even.formula_desc: Break-Even Point (Units) = Fixed Costs / (Price per Unit - Variable Cost per Unit)
break_even.use_case_1: Determine minimum sales to avoid loss

howItWorks.title: How Break-Even Analysis Works
howItWorks.formula: Break-Even Point = Fixed Costs / (Selling Price - Variable Cost per Unit)
howItWorks.explanation: Break-even analysis determines the point where total revenue equals total costs, resulting in neither profit nor loss. The contribution margin (selling price minus variable cost) represents how much each unit sold contributes to covering fixed costs.
steps: Enter your total fixed costs (rent, salaries, insurance, etc.)
Input the selling price per unit of your product or service
Enter the variable cost to produce or acquire each unit
The calculator divides fixed costs by the contribution margin
Result shows the number of units needed to break even

useCases.title: Pricing Strategy

seoTips: Calculate break-even before launching any new product or service to ensure viability
Review your break-even point quarterly as costs and prices change
Use break-even analysis to set minimum sales targets for your team
Consider multiple scenarios with different price points and cost structures
Factor in seasonal variations when planning around your break-even point

commonMistakes.title: Forgetting Hidden Fixed Costs
commonMistakes.description: Many businesses underestimate fixed costs by forgetting expenses like software subscriptions, insurance, professional fees, and depreciation.

commonMistakes.title: Misclassifying Variable Costs
commonMistakes.description: Some costs like utilities have both fixed and variable components. Accurately categorizing costs is essential for precise analysis.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Time Value
commonMistakes.description: Break-even analysis doesn't account for how long it takes to reach break-even. A longer timeline means more capital tied up and higher opportunity costs.

commonMistakes.title: Using Outdated Numbers
commonMistakes.description: Costs and prices change frequently. Running break-even analysis with outdated figures leads to poor decision-making.

faqs.question: What is a good break-even point?
faqs.answer: A good break-even point depends on your industry and business model. Generally, reaching break-even within 1-2 years for a new venture is considered reasonable. Lower break-even points provide more margin of safety.

faqs.question: How do I lower my break-even point?
faqs.answer: You can lower break-even by reducing fixed costs, decreasing variable costs per unit, or increasing your selling price. Each approach has trade-offs to consider.

faqs.question: What is contribution margin?
faqs.answer: Contribution margin is the selling price minus variable cost per unit. It represents how much each sale contributes toward covering fixed costs and generating profit.

faqs.question: Should I include taxes in break-even analysis?
faqs.answer: Basic break-even analysis typically excludes income taxes since taxes only apply when you're profitable. However, include sales taxes if they affect your pricing or cost structure.

faqs.question: How often should I recalculate break-even?
faqs.answer: Recalculate whenever significant changes occur to costs, prices, or product mix. At minimum, review quarterly to ensure your targets remain accurate.

faqs.question: What is a typical franchise fee?
faqs.answer: Varies widely: Fast food $25K-50K, retail $20K-40K, service $10K-30K. Premium brands like McDonald's or Chick-fil-A charge $45K+. Fee includes training and startup support.

faqs.question: What are royalty fees?
faqs.answer: Ongoing payments to the franchisor, typically 4-12% of gross revenue. They cover ongoing support, brand development, and franchisor profit.

faqs.question: Are franchise fees negotiable?
faqs.answer: Initial fees rarely. Some franchisors offer reduced fees for multi-unit deals, veterans, or minority owners. Royalties are generally fixed.

faqs.question: What is the marketing fund?
faqs.answer: A required contribution (1-4% of revenue) pooled for national/regional advertising. You must pay even if campaigns don't directly benefit your location.

faqs.question: What is the total investment for a franchise?
faqs.answer: Total investment includes franchise fee, real estate, buildout, equipment, inventory, and working capital. Typically ranges from $100K (service) to $2M+ (restaurants).

commonMistakes.title: Forgetting Hidden Costs

commonMistakes.title: Mixing One-Time and Recurring Costs

faqs.question: How much does it cost to start a business?
faqs.answer: Varies dramatically by type. Home-based service: $2,000-10,000. Retail store: $50,000-150,000. Restaurant: $175,000-750,000. Research your specific industry.

faqs.question: What is operating reserve and why is it important?
faqs.answer: Operating reserve is cash to cover expenses until the business generates enough revenue. Most businesses need 3-6 months of expenses. It prevents running out of money before reaching profitability.

faqs.question: Should I include personal expenses in startup costs?
faqs.answer: Yes, if you're leaving a job. Calculate personal living expenses for 6-12 months since you may not draw salary initially.

faqs.question: How do I fund my startup costs?
faqs.answer: Options include personal savings, friends/family, bank loans, SBA loans, angel investors, crowdfunding, or bootstrapping by starting small.

faqs.question: What costs can I reduce or eliminate?
faqs.answer: Start home-based, use used equipment, DIY marketing initially, start with minimum inventory, and consider virtual offices to reduce early costs.

howItWorks.explanation: Carriers charge based on the greater of actual weight or dimensional weight (calculated from package dimensions). Dimensional weight accounts for space the package occupies, not just its mass. This ensures fair pricing for lightweight but bulky items.

Input package dimensions (length, width, height)
Specify the shipping distance

Calculator determines billable weight and total shipping cost

commonMistakes.title: Using Incorrect Dimensions

commonMistakes.title: Not Comparing Carriers
commonMistakes.description: Rates vary significantly between carriers and service levels. Compare multiple options for each shipment type.

faqs.question: What is dimensional weight?
faqs.answer: Dimensional weight = (Length × Width × Height) / DIM factor. It calculates the 'theoretical' weight based on package size. Carriers charge whichever is greater: actual or dimensional weight.

faqs.question: How can I reduce shipping costs?
faqs.answer: Use smallest possible packaging, negotiate volume discounts, compare carriers, use regional carriers for local deliveries, and consider flat-rate options for heavy items.

faqs.question: What is the DIM factor?
faqs.answer: DIM divisor converts cubic dimensions to weight. Common factors: UPS/FedEx 139 (imperial) or 5000 (metric). Lower divisors result in higher dimensional weight charges.

faqs.question: Should I offer free shipping?
faqs.answer: Free shipping increases conversions but affects margins. Consider building shipping cost into product prices, setting minimum order thresholds, or offering as a promotion.

faqs.question: How do shipping zones affect cost?
faqs.answer: Zones represent distance from origin. Higher zones mean longer distances and higher costs. Locating fulfillment centers strategically can reduce average zone and shipping costs.

seoTips: Track productivity consistently - same time periods and measurement criteria for valid comparisons
Focus on sustainable productivity, not just peak performance periods
Consider quality alongside quantity - completed tasks should meet standards
Use productivity data to improve estimation accuracy over time
Account for different task complexity when comparing productivity across periods

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Task Complexity
commonMistakes.description: Not all tasks are equal. Completing 8 simple tasks isn't necessarily more productive than finishing 4 complex ones.

commonMistakes.title: Focusing Only on Speed
commonMistakes.description: Rushing to complete tasks quickly can sacrifice quality. True productivity balances speed with output quality.

commonMistakes.title: Not Accounting for Interruptions
commonMistakes.description: Meetings, emails, and unexpected issues affect actual work time. Factor these into realistic time allocations.

commonMistakes.title: Measuring Too Frequently
commonMistakes.description: Daily productivity fluctuates naturally. Weekly or bi-weekly measurements provide more meaningful trends.

faqs.question: What is a good productivity score?
faqs.answer: A score above 80% indicates excellent productivity. 60-80% is good, 40-60% is average, and below 40% suggests room for improvement. Context matters - some periods naturally have lower productivity.

faqs.question: How do I improve my productivity?
faqs.answer: Focus on better task estimation, minimize distractions, batch similar tasks, use time-blocking techniques, and regularly review what's working and what isn't.

faqs.question: Should I measure productivity daily or weekly?
faqs.answer: Weekly measurements are more reliable. Daily metrics fluctuate too much due to meeting days, unexpected issues, or task variations.

faqs.question: What if I complete more tasks than planned?
faqs.answer: Exceeding 100% completion indicates you may be underestimating capacity. Adjust future planning to better match your actual productivity level.

faqs.question: How do I account for different task types?
faqs.answer: Consider weighting tasks by complexity or estimated time. Alternatively, track productivity separately for different task categories.

quick_ratio.title: Quick Ratio Calculator

inputs.current_assets_tooltip: Assets convertible to cash within a year

info.title: About Quick Ratio
info.description: The Quick Ratio measures a company's ability to meet its short-term obligations with its most liquid assets.

howItWorks.title: How Quick Ratio Calculation Works
howItWorks.formula: Quick Ratio = (Current Assets - Inventory) / Current Liabilities
howItWorks.explanation: The quick ratio, also called the acid-test ratio, measures a company's ability to pay short-term obligations using only its most liquid assets. By excluding inventory (which may take time to sell), it provides a more conservative measure of liquidity than the current ratio.
steps: Enter total current assets (cash, receivables, marketable securities, inventory)
Input the value of inventory separately
Enter total current liabilities (debts due within one year)
Calculator subtracts inventory from current assets
Quick ratio is computed by dividing liquid assets by current liabilities

seoTips: A quick ratio of 1.0 or higher is generally considered healthy
Compare your quick ratio to industry benchmarks - acceptable ratios vary by sector
Track quick ratio alongside current ratio for complete liquidity picture
Seasonal businesses should calculate quick ratio at multiple points throughout the year
Rapidly increasing inventory with flat quick ratio may signal sales problems

commonMistakes.title: Using Book Values Instead of Market Values
commonMistakes.description: Marketable securities and receivables should reflect realistic collectible values, not just book values.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Receivables Quality
commonMistakes.description: Old receivables may not be collectible. Exclude significantly aged receivables from the calculation.

commonMistakes.title: Not Considering Timing
commonMistakes.description: A good quick ratio at year-end may mask mid-year liquidity problems. Monitor throughout the year.

commonMistakes.title: Cross-Industry Comparisons
commonMistakes.description: Acceptable quick ratios vary significantly by industry. Compare only within your sector.

faqs.question: What is a good quick ratio?
faqs.answer: Generally, a quick ratio of 1.0 or higher is good, meaning you can cover all current liabilities with liquid assets. However, ideal ratios vary by industry - retail may be lower, tech companies often higher.

faqs.question: What's the difference between quick ratio and current ratio?
faqs.answer: Current ratio includes all current assets including inventory. Quick ratio excludes inventory, providing a more conservative liquidity measure since inventory may not sell quickly.

faqs.question: Why exclude inventory from quick ratio?
faqs.answer: Inventory isn't immediately convertible to cash. It may take weeks or months to sell, and may need to be discounted. Liquid assets (cash, receivables, securities) can meet obligations faster.

faqs.question: Can quick ratio be too high?
faqs.answer: Yes. A very high quick ratio (above 2.0-3.0) may indicate inefficient use of assets. Cash sitting idle could be invested in growth or returned to shareholders.

faqs.question: How often should I calculate quick ratio?
faqs.answer: Monthly is ideal for internal monitoring. Quarterly for reporting purposes. More frequently during periods of financial stress or rapid growth.

working_capital.title: Working Capital Calculator

info.title: About Working Capital
info.description: Working Capital represents the difference between a company's current assets and current liabilities.

howItWorks.title: How Working Capital Calculation Works
howItWorks.formula: Working Capital = Current Assets - Current Liabilities
howItWorks.explanation: Working capital measures the short-term financial health of a business by comparing assets that can be converted to cash within a year against liabilities due within the same period. Positive working capital indicates ability to fund day-to-day operations and invest in growth.
steps: Enter total current assets (cash, inventory, receivables, prepaid expenses)
Input total current liabilities (payables, short-term debt, accrued expenses)
Calculator subtracts liabilities from assets
Positive result means excess liquidity; negative means potential cash shortage
Current ratio is also calculated (assets divided by liabilities)

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Working Capital Cycle
commonMistakes.description: Working capital needs fluctuate with business cycles. Annual averages may mask seasonal cash crunches.

commonMistakes.title: Including Non-Liquid Assets

commonMistakes.title: Overlooking Hidden Liabilities

commonMistakes.title: Not Considering Growth Needs
commonMistakes.description: Growth requires additional working capital. Adequate working capital today may be insufficient as sales increase.

faqs.question: What is healthy working capital?
faqs.answer: Generally, positive working capital with a current ratio between 1.5 and 2.0 is considered healthy. This varies by industry - grocery stores operate on lower ratios than manufacturers.

faqs.question: Can a profitable business have negative working capital?
faqs.answer: Yes. Some businesses like grocery stores collect cash immediately but pay suppliers later, operating successfully with negative working capital. However, this requires careful management.

faqs.question: How do I improve working capital?
faqs.answer: Collect receivables faster, negotiate longer payment terms with suppliers, reduce inventory levels, or secure a line of credit for short-term needs.

faqs.question: What's the difference between working capital and cash flow?
faqs.answer: Working capital is a balance sheet snapshot of short-term assets vs liabilities. Cash flow measures actual money movement over time. Both are important for financial health.

faqs.question: How much working capital do I need?
faqs.answer: Typically 2-3 months of operating expenses plus enough to fund inventory and receivables growth. Calculate your cash conversion cycle to determine specific needs.

faqs.question: What is a good current ratio?
faqs.answer: Generally, 1.5 to 2.0 is considered healthy. Below 1.0 signals potential liquidity problems. Above 3.0 may indicate inefficient asset use. Industry benchmarks vary significantly.

faqs.question: What's the difference between current ratio and quick ratio?
faqs.answer: Current ratio includes all current assets. Quick ratio excludes inventory, providing a more conservative liquidity measure. Use both for complete analysis.

faqs.question: Can current ratio be too high?
faqs.answer: Yes. Excessively high ratios (above 3.0) may indicate too much cash sitting idle, excess inventory, or inefficient receivables collection.

faqs.question: How do I improve my current ratio?
faqs.answer: Increase current assets by collecting receivables faster or building cash reserves. Decrease current liabilities by paying down short-term debt or negotiating longer payment terms.

faqs.question: How often should I calculate current ratio?
faqs.answer: Monthly for internal management. Quarterly for external reporting. More frequently during periods of financial stress or rapid change.

commonMistakes.description: Acceptable D/E ratios vary by industry. Utilities and real estate typically have higher ratios than technology companies.

commonMistakes.title: Using Only Short-Term Debt
commonMistakes.description: Include all debt - both short-term and long-term - for accurate leverage assessment.

commonMistakes.title: Not Considering Off-Balance Sheet Debt
commonMistakes.description: Operating leases and other commitments may not appear as debt but represent real financial obligations.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Interest Rates
commonMistakes.description: High debt at low interest rates may be less risky than moderate debt at high rates. Consider cost of debt alongside ratio.

faqs.question: What is a good debt-to-equity ratio?
faqs.answer: Generally, below 1.0 is conservative, 1.0-2.0 is moderate, and above 2.0 is high leverage. However, acceptable ratios vary significantly by industry.

faqs.question: Is higher or lower debt-to-equity better?
faqs.answer: It depends on your goals. Lower ratios mean less risk but potentially lower returns. Higher ratios can amplify returns but increase bankruptcy risk.

faqs.question: How does debt-to-equity affect stock price?
faqs.answer: High leverage increases volatility. Good times amplify gains; bad times amplify losses. Investors factor this risk into stock valuations.

faqs.question: What happens if debt-to-equity is negative?
faqs.answer: Negative ratio means negative equity (liabilities exceed assets), indicating severe financial distress or accumulated losses.

faqs.question: How do I lower my debt-to-equity ratio?
faqs.answer: Pay down debt, increase retained earnings, issue new equity, or sell assets to reduce debt. Avoid taking on additional debt.

Input the total number of impressions delivered

Lower CPM isn't always better - consider audience quality and relevance

Premium placements have higher CPM but may deliver better results

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Viewability
commonMistakes.description: Not all impressions are actually seen. Consider viewable CPM (vCPM) which only counts ads that were actually visible to users.

commonMistakes.title: Comparing Across Incompatible Formats
commonMistakes.description: Video, display, and native ads have different CPM ranges. Compare like with like for meaningful insights.

commonMistakes.title: Forgetting Audience Targeting
commonMistakes.description: Broader targeting typically has lower CPM but may reach less relevant audiences. Higher CPM with precise targeting often performs better.

commonMistakes.title: Not Considering Ad Quality
commonMistakes.description: Low CPM with poor ad creative wastes money. Invest in quality creative to maximize impression value.

faqs.question: What is a good CPM?
faqs.answer: Varies by platform and industry. Display ads: $1-5, Facebook: $5-15, LinkedIn: $30-60, Premium publishers: $15-50. Compare to your specific industry benchmarks.

faqs.question: What's the difference between CPM and CPC?
faqs.answer: CPM charges per 1,000 impressions regardless of clicks. CPC charges only when someone clicks. Use CPM for awareness, CPC for direct response campaigns.

faqs.question: How do I lower my CPM?
faqs.answer: Broaden targeting, adjust bidding strategy, test different placements, improve ad relevance scores, and run campaigns during lower-demand periods.

faqs.question: What is viewable CPM (vCPM)?
faqs.answer: vCPM only counts impressions where at least 50% of the ad was visible for at least 1 second. It's more accurate but typically costs more than standard CPM.

faqs.question: When should I use CPM bidding?
faqs.answer: Use CPM for brand awareness campaigns, product launches, or when you want maximum exposure. For lead generation or sales, CPC or CPA bidding is usually more efficient.

steps: Enter the total amount spent on your PPC campaign

Calculator divides total cost by total clicks

seoTips: Average CPC varies by industry: Legal $5-50, Insurance $15-50, Finance $3-12, E-commerce $0.50-2
Improve Quality Score to lower CPC - Google rewards relevant ads with lower costs
Use negative keywords to prevent wasted clicks and reduce overall CPC
Long-tail keywords typically have lower CPC and higher intent
Monitor CPC trends seasonally - competition varies throughout the year

commonMistakes.title: Focusing Only on CPC
commonMistakes.description: Low CPC is meaningless if clicks don't convert. Always consider conversion rate and cost per acquisition alongside CPC.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Quality Score
commonMistakes.description: Google uses Quality Score to determine CPC. Poor ad relevance or landing page experience inflates costs.

commonMistakes.title: Not Using Negative Keywords
commonMistakes.description: Irrelevant searches trigger ads and waste budget on useless clicks. Regularly review search terms and add negatives.

commonMistakes.title: Setting and Forgetting Bids
commonMistakes.description: CPC fluctuates with competition and seasonality. Regularly review and adjust bids for optimal performance.

faqs.question: What is a good CPC?
faqs.answer: Depends entirely on your industry and margins. If a click costs $2 and your conversion rate is 5% with $100 profit per sale, that's excellent. Calculate your maximum CPC based on your unit economics.

faqs.question: How do I reduce my CPC?
faqs.answer: Improve Quality Score with relevant ads and landing pages, use negative keywords, target long-tail keywords, improve ad relevance, and test different bidding strategies.

faqs.question: What's the difference between CPC and PPC?
faqs.answer: PPC (Pay Per Click) is the advertising model. CPC is the metric measuring what you pay per click. PPC campaigns are measured by CPC among other metrics.

faqs.question: Should I use manual or automated CPC bidding?
faqs.answer: Automated bidding works well with sufficient data (100+ conversions/month). Manual bidding gives more control but requires active management. Many advertisers use a hybrid approach.

faqs.question: Why is my CPC increasing?
faqs.answer: Common causes: increased competition, declining Quality Score, seasonal demand spikes, or changes to your targeting. Review search terms, ad relevance, and competitive landscape.

howItWorks.title: How CPA Calculation Works
howItWorks.formula: CPA = Total Marketing Cost / Total Conversions
howItWorks.explanation: CPA (Cost Per Acquisition) measures how much you spend to acquire one customer or conversion. It's the ultimate efficiency metric for performance marketing, connecting marketing spend directly to business outcomes like sales, sign-ups, or leads.
steps: Enter total marketing and advertising costs
Input the total number of conversions achieved
Calculator divides total cost by conversions
Result shows your average cost per acquisition
Compare to customer lifetime value to ensure profitability

useCases.title: Campaign Profitability Analysis
useCases.description: Determine if marketing campaigns are profitable by comparing CPA to customer lifetime value or profit per sale.

useCases.title: Channel Optimization
useCases.description: Compare CPA across marketing channels to allocate budget to the most efficient acquisition sources.

useCases.title: Budget Planning
useCases.description: Set marketing budgets based on target customer acquisition numbers and acceptable CPA thresholds.

useCases.title: Performance Benchmarking
useCases.description: Track CPA trends over time to measure marketing efficiency improvements and identify issues.

seoTips: Your maximum acceptable CPA should be less than customer lifetime value (LTV)
Track CPA by channel, campaign, and audience segment for optimization insights
Include all costs - agency fees, creative production, tools - not just ad spend
Benchmark against industry averages: E-commerce $10-50, SaaS $100-300, Finance $50-200
Optimize conversion rate to lower CPA without increasing ad spend

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Attribution
commonMistakes.description: Conversions often involve multiple touchpoints. Ensure your attribution model fairly credits channels to avoid misjudging CPA.

commonMistakes.title: Excluding Hidden Costs
commonMistakes.description: CPA should include all costs: ad spend, agency fees, creative production, tools, and team time. Partial costing understates true CPA.

commonMistakes.title: Not Accounting for Quality
commonMistakes.description: Not all conversions are equal. A channel with higher CPA may bring better customers with higher LTV.

commonMistakes.title: Short Attribution Windows
commonMistakes.description: Long sales cycles may show conversions after your tracking window closes. Adjust attribution windows to capture true CPA.

faqs.question: What is a good CPA?
faqs.answer: Good CPA depends on your margins. Rule of thumb: CPA should be 20-30% of customer lifetime value. If LTV is $500, target CPA under $100-150.

faqs.question: What's the difference between CPA and CAC?
faqs.answer: CPA typically refers to a single conversion. CAC (Customer Acquisition Cost) includes all sales and marketing costs to acquire a paying customer, including salaries and overhead.

faqs.question: How do I reduce CPA?
faqs.answer: Improve targeting to reach more qualified prospects, optimize landing pages for conversion, reduce wasted ad spend, and test different ad creatives and offers.

faqs.question: Should CPA include retargeting costs?
faqs.answer: Yes. Include all costs that contributed to the conversion. Some companies separate new customer CPA from remarketing CPA for clearer analysis.

faqs.question: What if my CPA exceeds customer value?
faqs.answer: You're losing money on acquisition. Either reduce marketing costs, increase conversion rates, improve customer retention/LTV, or adjust pricing.

howItWorks.title: How ROAS Calculation Works
howItWorks.formula: ROAS = Revenue from Ads / Ad Cost (or expressed as ratio like 4:1)
howItWorks.explanation: ROAS (Return on Ad Spend) measures how much revenue you generate for every dollar spent on advertising. A ROAS of 4:1 means you earn $4 for every $1 spent on ads. It's the key metric for determining advertising profitability and budget allocation.
steps: Enter total revenue attributed to advertising campaigns
Input total advertising cost for those campaigns
Calculator divides revenue by ad cost
Result shows your return multiplier (e.g., 4x or 400%)
Net profit is also calculated (revenue minus ad cost)

useCases.title: Channel Comparison

useCases.title: Scaling Decisions
useCases.description: Determine if campaigns can be profitably scaled by understanding ROAS at different spend levels.

seoTips: Minimum profitable ROAS depends on margins - 30% margin requires at least 3.3x ROAS to break even
Track ROAS by campaign, ad set, and creative level for granular optimization
Account for attribution model when comparing ROAS across channels
Average ROAS benchmarks: E-commerce 4:1, B2B 5:1, Brand campaigns 2:1
Consider customer lifetime value - lower initial ROAS may be acceptable for repeat customers

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Profit Margins
commonMistakes.description: High ROAS doesn't guarantee profit. If margins are 20%, you need 5x ROAS just to break even on ad spend.

commonMistakes.title: Attribution Errors
commonMistakes.description: Over-attributing or under-attributing revenue to ads distorts ROAS. Ensure your attribution model accurately reflects ad impact.

commonMistakes.title: Excluding Overhead Costs
commonMistakes.description: ROAS only compares revenue to ad spend. Profitability requires accounting for COGS, fulfillment, and other costs.

commonMistakes.title: Focusing on Short-Term ROAS
commonMistakes.description: Some campaigns build brand or acquire customers who purchase later. Evaluate longer-term ROAS for complete picture.

faqs.question: What is a good ROAS?
faqs.answer: Depends on profit margins. General benchmarks: 4:1 (400%) is good for e-commerce. Calculate your break-even ROAS: 1 / profit margin. If margin is 25%, break-even is 4x.

faqs.question: What's the difference between ROAS and ROI?
faqs.answer: ROAS measures revenue vs ad spend only. ROI accounts for all costs including product costs, overhead, and ad spend. ROAS of 4x might have negative ROI if margins are low.

faqs.question: How do I improve ROAS?
faqs.answer: Improve targeting to reach more buyers, test better ad creative, optimize landing pages, increase average order value, and reduce wasted spend on non-converting audiences.

faqs.question: Should I pause campaigns with low ROAS?
faqs.answer: Not always. Some campaigns drive brand awareness or influence customers who convert through other channels. Evaluate incrementality and attribution before pausing.

faqs.question: Why does ROAS decrease as I scale?
faqs.answer: As you spend more, you exhaust high-intent audiences and reach less qualified prospects. Diminishing returns are normal - find the optimal spend level for your goals.

faqs.question: What is a good conversion rate?
faqs.answer: Varies by industry. E-commerce: 2-3% average, 5%+ is excellent. B2B lead gen: 2-5%. SaaS free trial: 3-5%. Always compare to your industry and historical performance.

faqs.question: How do I improve conversion rate?
faqs.answer: Improve page load speed, simplify forms, add trust signals, use clear CTAs, optimize for mobile, show social proof, and continuously A/B test elements.

faqs.question: Should I track conversion rate or total conversions?
faqs.answer: Both matter. Conversion rate measures efficiency; total conversions measure volume. You need traffic AND conversion rate for results.

faqs.question: Why is my mobile conversion rate lower?
faqs.answer: Mobile users face more friction: smaller screens, typing difficulties, distractions. Optimize checkout, use mobile payment options, and simplify forms.

faqs.question: How many visitors do I need for valid conversion rate?
faqs.answer: For reliable data, aim for at least 100 conversions. For A/B testing, use a significance calculator to determine required sample size.

faqs.question: What is a good engagement rate?
faqs.answer: Instagram: 3-6% is good, above 6% excellent. Twitter: 0.5-1% is good. LinkedIn: 2-5% is good. Rates decrease as follower count increases.

faqs.question: Why is my engagement rate dropping?
faqs.answer: Common causes: algorithm changes, content fatigue, follower growth without engagement growth, posting at wrong times, or content quality decline.

faqs.question: How do I improve engagement rate?
faqs.answer: Post consistently, respond to comments, use calls-to-action, post at optimal times, create shareable content, use relevant hashtags, and engage with your community.

faqs.question: Is follower count or engagement rate more important?
faqs.answer: Engagement rate. 10,000 engaged followers are more valuable than 100,000 passive ones. Focus on building an active community.

faqs.question: How do I calculate engagement rate for influencer partnerships?
faqs.answer: Request their average engagement rate across recent posts (not their best posts). Verify by calculating it yourself from their public posts.

amazon_fba.title: Amazon FBA Calculator
amazon_fba.description: Calculate Amazon FBA fees including referral fees, fulfillment fees, and storage costs to determine your profit margins.

inputs.product_price_tooltip: The selling price of your product on Amazon
inputs.product_cost_tooltip: Your cost to manufacture or source the product

results.formula_desc: Total Fees = Referral Fee + FBA Fulfillment Fee + Monthly Storage Fee

info.title: About Amazon FBA Calculator
info.description: Calculate all Amazon FBA costs including referral fees, fulfillment fees, and storage fees to understand your true profit margins when selling on Amazon.
info.use_case_2: Set competitive prices that maintain margins
info.use_case_3: Compare FBA costs to FBM (Fulfilled by Merchant)

ebay_fees.title: eBay Fees Calculator
ebay_fees.description: Calculate eBay selling fees including insertion fees, final value fees, and payment processing fees.

inputs.sale_price_tooltip: The price the item sold for on eBay
inputs.product_cost_tooltip: Your cost to acquire or produce the item
inputs.shipping_charge_tooltip: Amount charged to buyer for shipping
inputs.shipping_cost_tooltip: Your actual cost to ship the item

results.formula_desc: Total Fees = Insertion Fee + Final Value Fee + Payment Processing Fee

info.title: About eBay Fees Calculator
info.description: Calculate all eBay selling fees to understand your net profit after insertion fees, final value fees, and payment processing costs.
info.use_case_1: Determine minimum selling price for profitability
info.use_case_2: Compare eBay fees across different categories
info.use_case_3: Calculate total profit after all fees and shipping

income_tax.title: Income Tax Calculator
income_tax.description: Calculate federal income tax based on your income, filing status, and deductions.
income_tax.gross_income_tooltip: Your total annual income before taxes

results.formula_desc: Tax = Progressive tax based on income brackets

project_budget.title: Project Budget Calculator
project_budget.description: Calculate total project budget including materials, labor, overhead, and contingency.

inputs.materials_cost_tooltip: Total cost of all materials and supplies
inputs.labor_cost_tooltip: Total cost for labor and contractors
inputs.overhead_cost_tooltip: Indirect costs like insurance, permits, utilities

info.title: About Project Budget Calculator

shopify_profit.title: Shopify Profit Calculator
shopify_profit.description: Calculate net profit after Shopify fees, payment processing, and shipping costs.

inputs.product_cost_tooltip: Your cost to produce or source the product
inputs.shipping_charge_tooltip: Amount charged to customer for shipping

results.formula_desc: Net Profit = Revenue - Product Cost - Shipping Cost - Shopify Fees - Payment Fees

info.title: About Shopify Profit Calculator
info.description: Calculate your true profit after all Shopify transaction fees, payment processing fees, and shipping costs.
info.use_case_3: Calculate margins for product sourcing decisions

inputs.hours_worked_tooltip: Total billable hours on the project
inputs.expenses_tooltip: Additional expenses to bill to client

info.title: About Time Tracking Calculator
info.description: Calculate invoices for hourly work including labor and reimbursable expenses for freelancers and consultants.

unit_cost.title: Unit Cost Calculator
unit_cost.description: Calculate the cost per unit based on fixed costs, variable costs, and production volume.

inputs.variable_costs_tooltip: Total variable costs (materials, labor per unit)

results.formula_desc: Unit Cost = (Fixed Costs + Variable Costs) / Units Produced

info.title: About Unit Cost Calculator
info.description: Calculate the cost to produce each unit including both fixed and variable costs for pricing and profitability analysis.
